awd_titl_txt: Massive Star Birth, Life and Death: Closing the Loop in the Local Group of Galaxies
awd_abstract_narration:
Massive stars are the 'cosmic engines' of the Universe.  These stars shine because of nuclear reactions in their cores.  This process also has made most of the oxygen and carbon atoms that exist today.  When these massive stars die, lighter elements are turned into heavier ones, such as iron.  We are literally made up of this 'star stuff'.  These stars also give off so much energy that they cause new stars to form.    Although we understand most kinds of stars pretty well, there are many things about massive stars that remain a mystery.  The goal of this project is to see how well our theories work by comparing predictions against observations.  This project will give us a clearer picture of what happens as a massive star ages.  The investigators will compare the type of stars found in different nearby galaxies, using data taken on large telescopes in Arizona and in Chile.   This project will also fund two early-career research students, and provide research projects for two undergraduates.

The investigators will study massive stars in several ways. They plan to observe Local Group galaxies, which are close enough to be studied in great detail. They will observe all massive stars in these galaxies. Specifically they will determine 1) how changing orbits of binary stars modify the element formation in massive stars and 2) how the most massive stars end their lives. 

The investigator and his collaborators have begun a survey for Wolf-Rayet (WR) stars in the Magellanic Clouds. With half of the area covered, the project has already confirmed the existence of 15 new WR stars, 10 of which appear to be a new type, never before seen. These discoveries suggest that the population of WR stars in the Magellanic Clouds may have been underestimated by as much as 40%, and yet for decades the Magellanic Clouds have served as the linchpins for evaluating massive star models at low metallicities. When complete, the Magellanic Cloud WR Survey will permit the determination of what fraction of WR stars have changed through binary interactions (Roche-lobe overflow) and fraction show changes in element abundance through single-star material losses due to stellar winds. Thirty WR binaries have been identified in M31 and M33, and repeated radial velocity measurements are being made with the 6.5-m MMT telescope, along with photometric monitoring at Lowell Observatory?s new 4.3-m telescope. This project will provide similar data on the frequency of binary interactions at higher metallicity, and provide direct measurements of the masses of WR stars for comparison with model predictions. The nature of the mysterious, oxygen-rich, WR stars (WO stars) will be explored by determining accurate surface abundances of carbon and oxygen. Comparing these observations to models will determine if the WO stars are truly the "last hurrah" of the most massive stars.  Each of these experiments provides a key piece of information to improve models of massive star nuclear energy production. 

The investigator will bring undergraduates into his research program, providing a boost to students from small, liberal arts colleges.  This experience enables their students to successfully compete for entrance to best graduate schools in the country. These students are drawn from the REU program administered through Northern Arizona University, as well as Lowell Observatory's MIT Field Camp, which now includes students from the all-women?s Wellesley College.

por.por_cntn:
Massive stars are often described as the "cosmic engines" of the universe.  Although these stars are rare, they manufacture most of the heavy elements: the oxygen you breath, the iron in your blood, the silver and gold in your jewery were all manufactured in the cores of massive stars.  Our proposal was aimed at answering at providing the observational base against which theoretical models of massive stars could be compared.

For this, we made observations with large telescopes in Chile and in Arizona, studying the massive star content of nearby galaxies, such as the Large and Small Magellanic Clouds (LMC, SMC)  and the Andromeda (M31) and Triangulum (M33) galaxies.  Our research included the unevolved massive stars, such a O and B-type stars, and their evolved descendants, the red supergiants (RSGs) and Wolf-Rayet (WR) stars.

Products. The grant has supported the work for 23 refereed papers.  Thirteen of these papers were led by students; two were invited reviews.  The grant supported two contributed talks at the 2017 New Zealand IAU Symposium 329 on massive stars and two invited talks at the 2018 Argentina ``Nidiafest" massive star meeting .  It supported the PI's involvement in eleven posters at seven AAS meetings, eight of which were presented by undergraduate or graduate students.

Intellectual Merit.  The project has enabled three major discoveries, and several minor surprises:

1. The Nature of A New Type of Wolf-Rayet Star.  Prior to this grant, we had discovered a new type of Wolf-Rayet star in the Large Magellanic Cloud as part of a survey for WRs in the Magellanic Clouds.  The NSF grant allowed us to complete the survey, discovering nine of these ``WN3/O3" stars; it also supported the modeling of their spectra, leading to an understanding of their physical properties. 

2. Red Supergiant Binaries.  This grant enabled Massey's involvement in the discovery of the first extragalactic RSG binaries, including supporting all of the Magellan and MMT observing associated with Neugent's work.  

3. RSG Mass-Loss Rates.  We used UKIRT near-IR photometry of M31 to determine the luminosity function of RSGs, and used this to demonstrate that recently revised RSG mass-loss rates used in both the Geneva and BPASS models are correct. 

Minor Surprises.  Several unexpected discoveries came our way, including finding the first halo runaway star whose origin could be kinematically traced to the Milky Way's supermassive black hole.

 Broader Impacts. We identify two areas where AST-1612874 made a difference:

1.Increased representation of women. This grant provided research opportunities for four women, including enabling two PhD theses and a Masters thesis, and providing projects for several undergraduates. (a) Kathryn Neugent, a long-time Lowell colleague, decided to obtain her PhD.  Her first step was to enroll in the Masters Program in Physics at Northern Arizona University (NAU).  The NSF grant covered all of the ground-based observing associated with her thesis work,  as well as Massey's participation in the project.  She graduated with distinction in 2018, entering the PhD program at the University of Washington with Dr. Emily Levesque.  They enlisted Massey to help with the observing for her thesis studies of RSG binaries described above; the grant provided support for four trips to use Magellan at Las Campanas as part of this new project, as well as to the 6.5-m MMT telescope on Mt. Hopkins.  The grant also covered her travel  for an invited presentation at IAU 329 in New Zealand and an invited talk at the ``Nidiafest" meeting in Argentina.   (b) Erin Aadland entered the PhD program at NAU in the Fall of 2018.  Her work modeling the properties of WC WRs was supported through a NASA ADAP grant.  However, the NSF grant covered her travel to Magellan for additional optical observing. It also covered her work on a side-project studying the spatial isolation of Luminous Blue Variable stars, which she published as first-author.  (c) The grant has covered the PI's participation in REU projects each year, with students Hannah Umansky (Univ. Virginia), and Victoria Leger (Penn State), each of whom worked on ground-based spectroscopy of massive star-forming regions in nearby galaxies.  2. Heuristic material. (a) One of our ``products" was a comprehensive review paper of WRs in the galaxies of the Local Group and beyond..  Another was a review paper of massive stars in the Local Group, invited as part of the ``Bridging the Gap" conference.  Such reviews have proven very useful, particularly for early-career researchers entering the field.  (b)  During the pandemic, the PI contributed to Lowell's public outreach videos ``How Stars Work," ``Observing the Universe from Chile," and ``The Great Dimming of Betelgeuse,"  all incorporating results from our NSF-supported research.
